Yes, the position of a company secretary is generally considered sufficient to meet the criterion for being an officer of the company when claiming Business Asset Disposal Relief (BADR). A company secretary is a recognized officer of a company under UK law and has various legal responsibilities and duties.

To recap, in order to qualify for BADR, the individual shareholder must meet the following conditions:

1. The company must be a trading company or the holding company of a trading group.
2. The shareholder must hold at least 5% of the ordinary shares and voting rights in the company for at least 24 months before the disposal.
3. The shareholder must be an officer or employee of the company or a member of its trading group for at least 24 months before the disposal.

As a company secretary, you would typically satisfy the third condition as an officer of the company, assuming you meet the other qualifying conditions. However, it's always recommended to consult with a qualified tax advisor to discuss your specific circumstances and ensure that you meet all the conditions for BADR.
